total_impedance_ori_txt.item: R1 and Re0 connected in series so Rd0=R1+Re0=4 Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33 Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33 Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.33 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 10.33 Ohm

total_impedance_txt.item: R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd0=R1+R3=4 Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33 Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33 Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.33 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 10.33 Ohm

total_impedance_ori_txt.item: R4 and Re1 connected in series so Rd1=R4+Re1=9 Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64 Ohm
Rc1 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+R1=2.64 Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 5.64 Ohm

total_impedance_txt.item: R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=9 Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64 Ohm
Rc1 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+R1=2.64 Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 5.64 Ohm

request.text: What is the voltage on VM1?

solution.item: We have more than one generator so we are using superposition to calculate voltages/currents.
This is a DC calculation
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS2)
R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd0=R1+R3=4 Ohm
R5 and Rd0 connected in parallel so Rc0=R5*Rd0/(R5+Rd0)=1.33 Ohm
R2 and Rc0 connected in series so Rb0=R2+Rc0=5.33 Ohm
Rb0 and R4 connected in series so Ra0=Rb0+R4=10.33 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 10.33 Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R5
We know that the voltage between VS2 nodes is 4 V.
All generators except for VS2 have been replaced with a short circuit.
(1) The components Rb0,R4 connected in series.
(1) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 4 V.
(1) Rb0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb0 is Rb0/Ra0*4 V = 2.06 V.
(2) The components R2,Rc0 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.06 V.
(2) Rc0 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc0 is Rc0/Rb0*2.06 V = 0.52 V.
(3) The components R5,Rd0 connected in parallel. The voltage on R5 is 0.52 V because the voltage on Rc0 is 0.52 V
This is a DC calculation
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd1=R4+R2=9 Ohm
R5 and Rd1 connected in parallel so Rc1=R5*Rd1/(R5+Rd1)=1.64 Ohm
Rc1 and R1 connected in series so Rb1=Rc1+R1=2.64 Ohm
R3 and Rb1 connected in series so Ra1=R3+Rb1=5.64 Ohm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 5.64 Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R5
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 6 V.
All generators except for VS1 have been replaced with a short circuit.
(4) The components R3,Rb1 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 6 V.
(4) Rb1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb1 is Rb1/Ra1*6 V = 2.81 V.
(5) The components Rc1,R1 connected in series.
(5) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.81 V.
(5) Rc1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc1 is Rc1/Rb1*2.81 V = 1.74 V.
(6) The components R5,Rd1 connected in parallel. The voltage on R5 is 1.74 V because the voltage on Rc1 is 1.74 V
Now we are using superposition to calculate the voltage on R5
Let's summarize the calculations from the previous section.
When you see subtraction here it means that the original direction reversed.
The direction of voltage/current determined by propagating the direction of the source.
To answer the original question: because the VM1 voltmeter connected to R5 parallel so the voltage on VM1 is 2.26 V
We have considered also that the polarity of the volt meter does not match the voltage direction on R5
